title.narrative: Building Capacity to Counter Illegal Mining

description.narrative: Build Capacity to Counter Illegal Mining in Mongolia Covers grants (including revenue- sharing), subsidies, gratuities, and other aid for which cash payments are made to states, other political subdivisions, corporations, associations, and individuals; contributions to international societies, commissions, proceedings, or projects, whether in lump sum or as quotas of expenses; contributions fixed by treaty; grants to foreign countries; taxes imposed by taxing authorities where the Federal Government has consented to taxation (excluding the employers share of Federal Insurance Contribution Act taxes); and payments in lieu of taxes. Includes readjustment and other benefits for veterans, other than indemnities for death or disability.

title.narrative: Preservation and Protection of the 17th-Century Duut Khad Stone Inscription

description.narrative: A 30-line poem inscribed on three different rocks during the 17th century, the Duut Khad stone inscription is of great value in understanding the language, literature, and art of the period. This project involves a condition assessment, development of a cultural resources management plan, and a public awareness campaign focused on Mongolian traditional script.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

transaction.usg:treasury-account: Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs
Department of State, Diplomatic and Consular Programs

title.narrative: Restoration of Fire-Damaged Paintings in the Collection of the Mongolian National Modern Art Gallery, Phase 2

description.narrative: To support the continuation of work begun under a previous Ambassadors Fund grant to restore fire-damaged paintings in the Mongolian National Modern Art Gallery in Ulaanbaatar. The museums collection of nearly 1,300 paintings represents the development of modern painting in Mongolia, and 70 percent of it was either destroyed or damaged by fire in May 2009. This phase of the project involves the cleaning of approximately 375 damaged paintings.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Conservation of Endangered Textiles of the Mongol Empire (13th-14th Centuries) and Other Periods

description.narrative: Mongolians have long used textiles to represent individual and familial authority, cultural sophistication, and wealth. This project involves the conservation of historic textiles and training in textile conservation for Mongolian museum professionals.

title.narrative: Conservation of the Early 20th-Century Yadam Temple at the Choijin Lama Temple Museum in Ulaanbaatar

description.narrative: The Yadam was once a private prayer hall for Choijin Lama Luvsankhaidav, the official state oracle of Mongolia from 1911-1918. This project involves the conservation of the temple and capacity building in traditional crafts and conservation techniques.

title.narrative: Documentation of the Collections of the National Museum of Mongolia

description.narrative: The National Museum is home to over 56,000 prehistoric and historic objects. This project involves the development of a barcode inventory system to improve the museums management of the collections.

title.narrative: Training in the Preventive Conservation of Museum Collections

description.narrative: Mongolias museums are the modern-day keepers of thousands of objects and records from the countrys illustrious past and major drivers of cultural tourism development. title.narrative: Mongolia Child Protection Compact

description.narrative: To support the U.S. commitments outlined in the Child Protection Compact (CPC) Partnership, an agreement that was developed jointly with the Government of Mongolia to support enhanced and more effective efforts to address child trafficking. Building on the strong foundation of the Mongolian governments anti-trafficking efforts, WV will work to achieve improved, sustainable policies and practices that ensure effective interagency coordination and collaboration on child trafficking efforts; hold perpetrators of child trafficking criminally accountable; provide comprehensive and trauma-informed protective services for child victims; and, prevent child trafficking from occurring.

title.narrative: Conservation of the Late 19th-Century Leopard Skin Ger of Bogd Khaan

description.narrative: The Leopard Skin Ger was a personal belonging of the last King of Mongolia. This project includes the conservation of the ger's interior and exterior, including the outer leopard skin covering and inner silk lining. The project directly supports the Embassy's efforts to demonstrate American respect for the cultural heritage of Mongolia and to raise the profileof the United States within the country.

title.narrative: Preservation of Archaeological Sites of the Ikh Nart Nature Reserve in Eastgobi Aimag

description.narrative: The archaeological heritage of this vast region is extremely rich, ranges in age from the Neolithic Period to the 20th century, but is largely unknown and in urgent need of documentation and protection against vandalism and looting. This project involves survey, documentation, and registration of sites, and education and outreach activities.

person-name.narrative: Jenee Sharon; Wes Aviles; Ryan Boles

title.narrative: Diagnosing and repairing FLIR cameras

description.narrative: Diagnosing and repairing FLIR cameras Includes all contractual costs of maintenance and repair of security equipment and security related equipment such as shredders, closed- circuit TV systems, etc., both domestic and abroad. Does not include IT and communications security related equipment. Includes miscellaneous repairs and maintenance of equipment for O/S LGP under function 5820 and subfunctions 5821, 5822, 5823, and 5824, as applicable.
